title: (x) Oakwood Worldwide script logo - similar to Snell Roundhand {Stephen}
content:
I’ve been trying to find a typeface close to the “OAKWOOD” part of the attached GIF.  
Any help would be appreciated.  
(I’m not really concerned with the other 2 typefaces in the GIF but if you happen to know those I’m not going to complain :)  
Thanks !

- Sandro

If anyone is interested in seeing it in context the website that it came from is here :  
 [http://www.oakwood.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20061202100612/http:/www.oakwood.com/)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [header\_logo-oakwood.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20061202100612/http:/typophile.com/files/header_logo-oakwood.gif) | 5.74 KB |
author: spellegrini

comments.content: [Snell Roundhand Black](http://web.archive.org/web/20061202100612/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=LH.562.0.3&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=Oakwood+&sampleSize=48) is closest I can get.
that’s quite close - thanks, better than what I’ve found

I believe you can do better than that, since the lower case is very close to a number of formal script styles. (I think the ‘O’ is not from a script face at all — probably an italic ‘O’.)

For the lower case, have a look at [Shelley Andante](http://web.archive.org/web/20061202100612/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/shelley-script/) (or Allegro, for that matter, since the l.c. is the same). Others could be Palace Script, or Embassy Script, but you would want to flatten and bold them a bit. Look for the un-looped ascenders. There are a number in the Solotype Catalog in the Z-families, so this may have come from a film type. Some were digitized.

- Mike Yanega
